data.title: Atom freezes when remounting drive
data.body:
I'm running Windows 10 with a guest VM that runs Debian, which I use as my development web server. Within Windows, I have mapped a network drive to the VM webroot folder, which contains my projects. I use Atom to directly edit files on this mapped drive, which generally works well.

This setup does have incidental issues, which I would like to share. 

First, if I shut down my VM whilst having Atom open, it freezes. Somewhat understandable, since the mapped drive is unmounted and Atom can no longer find the files, but it would be nicer to have a clean exit or detection of this state, instead of just hanging forever.

Second, if I then start up the VM again and confirm in Windows explorer that the files are accessible again, if I then start up Atom, it again hangs forever. Only a Windows reboot seems to solve that.

I know that this bug will be hard to reproduce as it requires a very specific setup, but I want to share it anyway. Atom is by far my favorite editor feature-wise, but due to so many random freezes where I have no idea what it is doing, I keep switching back to editors that just work.

data.title: Removing file from stage with git breaks Atom git-integration
data.body:
### Description

If you use `git reset HEAD <filename>` to remove a file from staging that has been modified in Atom the git information highlighting stops working. It doesn't change state and shows outdated git information.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `File -> Add Project Folder` (needs to be a git-Project)
2. Add two Files `foo.js` and `bar.js` and make changes to both
3. Use your command line to execute `git add all` in your project directory
4. Remove one file from the staging area `git reset HEAD foo.js`
5. Go back into Atom, `foo.js` is still marked as staged

**Expected behavior:**
`foo.js` is marked as either newly-added or modified.

**Actual behavior:**
`foo.js` is marked as staged.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.9.5
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.15.8
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

data.title: Closing Atom and re-opening doesn't save the files etc. I had open
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? _(to the best of my knowledge)_
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? _I think so, but maybe I should see the developers of [save-session](https://atom.io/packages/save-session) as well_
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Whenever I close atom, after working on a project, the project is seemingly "lost."

Upon re-opening of atom, none of the tabs I had open, none of the project folders I had open, are retained.

I made a short 2-minute video to demonstrate: https://sendvid.com/qocn3pz4

As you can see, no matter how I close the editor (via CMD+Q or the Red X) the problem ensues.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open atom.
2. Add project folder, open some files, open some tabs, just normal routine.
3. Close and re-open atom.

**Expected behavior:** Atom would remember all the files and folders I had open, and present me with an editor in exactly the same state as when I quit the Application.

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens a blank (empty) editor, without any documents open (I have "Open blank editor on startup" set to false)
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.9.8
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4
```

I am using Mac OSX El Capitan 10.11.6

data.title: Atom reverted to base install, deleted all themes/packages
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?

Not entirely sure about this.
- [ ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

Yes. I have "install new updates on restart" enabled.
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?

I asked on Slack (atomio.slack.com) and one user mentioned how I should definitely file an issue for this. I've never seen or heard any application delete all packages and user settings based on application close. 
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

Just performed cursory search, no issues like this open. 
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?

This happened to the Atom editor. 
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

Just did, this was not a crash (closed properly), but when it restarted all the packages were missing.

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom deleted all of my packages and themes upon application restart. Not really sure how else to elaborate on this, but pretty much reverted to base install (maybe more basic as file explorer is not present on left-hand-side as well).  
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have a lot of tabs open (I had my React project open at the time and had my README.md, and many Javascript files)
2. Notable installed packages include those needed to run .eslintrc file (eslint-plugin-{react, lodash, etc.}, eslint)
3. Delete tabs by using shortcut Cmd + W really fast
4. Reopen Atom by typing in Terminal atom . in targeted directory
5. cry

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Atom closes and starts up again with all packages and themes present. File explorer present on left hand side. 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Atom deleted all themes and packages. ~/.atom directory still exists, ~/.atom/packages does not. No green square on bottom-left-hand-side (not sure if I should be looking for this.)
Still present: all directory files (Atom did not touch any of my files, and since I had just pushed to devel branch there weren't any unsaved changes to any files so I don't know if those would have been lost or not).
### Versions

Atom 1.9.8 
apm 1.10.0
OS: OS X 10.11.5

data.title: Replace Grunt-based build system with simple scripts
data.body:
Our existing Grunt-based build system is really difficult to follow, so this PR replaces it with a simpler approach involving plain old JavaScript.

The `build` directory is deleted, and instead the `script` directory takes on an expanded role, getting its own `package.json` and `lib` directories to support an overhauled version of `script/bootstrap`, `script/build`, and `script/test`. Instead of relying on Grunt, we do everything via functions defined in the `script/lib` directory.
### Build script

The _basic_ structure of the new build script is as follows:
- Copy all sources to `atom/out/app`
- Transpile Babel, CoffeeScript, and Less files in place
- Generate pre-cached metadata
- At this point, `out/app` is a valid Electron app that doesn't require transpilation support to run.
- Run [`electron-packager`](https://github.com/electron-userland/electron-packager) on `out/app` to package it into a distributable application on the current platform.
- Build installer on Windows, code sign on macOS
- Zip stuff up

This is all designed to run only on third-party build providers (CircleCI for macOS, Travis for Linux, and AppVeyor on Windows). We've put zero effort into making these scripts run on internal Janky boxes.
### Release publishing plan

We deliberately omit the artifact uploading step, because our plan is to orchestrate release publishing outside of the build. We'll rely on the build services to store artifacts associated with all builds, and when we're ready to release we'll have a script download these artifacts from Circle, Travis, and AppVeyor and upload them to the releases API and S3. This will help to ensure that all artifacts stay in sync based on a specific commit SHA.
### Tasks
- [x] Build scripts working on all platforms
  - [x] macOS
    - [x] Build a complete electron app
    - [x] Code sign
    - [x] Green build on Circle
    - [x] Implement `--install` flag
  - [x] Windows
    - [x] Build a complete electron app
    - [x] Build an installer
    - [x] Delete unnecessary .nupkg delta file uploaded as artifact
    - [x] Code sign
    - [x] Green build on AppVeyor
    - [x] Installing won't be supported, because users can launch the generated installer.
  - [x] Linux
    - [x] Build a complete electron app 
    - [x] Generate `.deb` package
    - [x] Generate `.rpm` package
    - [x] Green build on Travis
    - [x] Make Travis artifacts downloadable
    - [x] Installing won't be supported, because users can launch the package manager on the generated packages.
- [x] Add `script/lint`
- [x] Release publishing
  - [x] Visualize build status for release branch across all platforms
  - [x] Download and publish artifacts for a specific SHA
  - [x] Authenticate Atom maintainers that work for GitHub
  - [x] Get app running on Heroku Enterprise
  - [x] A pinch of styling
- [x] Documentation
  - [x] Rewrite build instructions for macOS
  - [x] Rewrite build instructions for Windows
  - [x] Rewrite build instructions for Linux
- [x] Ops
  - [x] Make builds a no-op on previous internal build systems.
  - [x] Eliminate atom-private AppVeyor build and use private env vars instead

data.title: Mock clock and animation frames in TextEditorComponent specs
data.body:
A few months ago, I rewrote the editor tests to use real timers and animation frames to address coverage gaps in the existing tests. Unfortunately, it's proven extremely difficult to make these tests run reliably on CI.

We plan to extract the editor completely soon, at which point it may be worth another try to implement more realistic tests, though doing so will probably require a careful look at the many nuanced time-sensitive sequences of operations that occur within the editor. Until then, I'm going back to a less realistic but more reliable approach to testing this component.

data.title: Use generic icon in linux .desktop file instead of hard coded path
data.body:
Instead of hard coding the icon path in the `.desktop` file it is much more common to just state the appname and place the default logo at `/usr/share/icons/hicolor/`_`resolution`_`/apps/atom.png`. Chrome for example does so. However this is not simply a cosmetic change! It also allows for themes to replace certain icons while preserving the icons of apps with no altered icon.

The bug is still present in the master branch as of now.

data.title: #12386 Splitting panes using the menu gives me an empty panel
No syntax highlighting for large SQL files
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

OS: Windows 10
Atom: v1.9.8

@mojombo @Caged @schacon @defunkt @benburkert 
### Description

No syntax highlighting for large SQL files

Hi guys,
Recently, I've been working quite more with databases and SQL. But I noticed in `v1.9.8` and some older versions that when I open an already existing large `*.sql` file, Atom doesn't highlight the code. I tried it in safe mode but still got the same issue even when I switched syntax themes.

Atom only highlights large SQL code when I create a new untitled file and set the type to SQL and paste or type SQL code into it.

**Expected Behavior:** Atom highlights all the code in my SQL file.

**Actual Behavior:** No highlights for the SQL code at all in a file except when in an untitled file.

Some help would be appreciated. Thanks

data.title: Atom crashed when open a folder
data.body:
### Description

Atom crashed when open a folder. Please see screenshot of all files in my "bug" folder.

http://image.prntscr.com/image/90c1244fca1e41b88cdc50cd3339ea5a.png

I don't know why but it's working with other folders.
### Steps to Reproduce
- Open folder in Atom with folder context menu
- Open folder in Atom from File -> Open Folder...

**Expected behavior:** Folder opened with Atom

**Actual behavior:** Please see this screenshot: http://image.prntscr.com/image/192d9121e71b4725a854ce07d138402c.png
### Versions

I'm using Atom 1.9.8 on Windows 7 64 bit.

data.title: PATH env being changed randomly
data.body:
Gentoo Linux KDE5 desktop, atom v1.9.7.
I met a strange issue. atom sometimes reports that it cannot find some base comands.
for example,
Uncaught BufferedProcessError: Failed to spawn command `find`. Make sure `find` is installed and on your PATH
and basename,dirname,etc.
When restart atom,  the problem is gone. 
Is it the PATH env problem?

data.title: Takes very long when multiple atom windows are quitted and re-opened
data.body: When atom is restoring last session , it hits IO 99% about same amount of windows opned , very very slow to start (takes 10 mins) since every atom processes are trying to steal each other IO resources.

data.title: Settings got resetted when opening multiple windows at once.
data.body:
When atom is quitted using Ctrl + Q and when new windows are opened all settings are resetting.
Including disabled plugins.

data.title: Add help, don't build winstaller by default, add skip
data.body:
1. Adds help for the build script to clarify options up-front
2. Does not build Windows installer by default as it is SLOW

data.title: Fix Regression In #12317 For zsh and Patch Environment On OSX For Users Of fish
data.body:
In Atom 1.7 and 1.8, the environment would be patched for users of the zsh shell on OS X, who launched Atom from the Dock / Finder / Spotlight. A whitelist of shells was established in #12317, which is extended here to include zsh and fish.

Tested with built-in zsh, homebrew installed zsh, and homebrew installed fish.

data.title: Give each integration test its own ATOM_HOME
data.body:
We symlink the compile cache from the original ATOM_HOME to ensure window startup is still performant, but avoid anything else leaking across tests.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld
